questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 39 weeks gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. On examination, the cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated. After 5 minutes of pushing, there is a prolonged deceleration of the fetal heart rate to 90/min. A decision to perform an episiotomy is made to expedite vaginal delivery. The anesthesiologist locates the ischial spines by palpating the posterolateral vaginal sidewall and administers an anesthetic. Three minutes later, pinching the posterior vulva does not provoke pain. The anesthetized nerve most likely also supplies which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The obturator externus is innervated by the obturator nerve. This nerve also innervates a small area of skin on the medial thigh, as well as the gracilis, pectineus, obturator externus, and adductor magnus, longus, and brevis muscles. Obturator nerve blocks are achieved with anesthetic injection into the medial thigh, not intravaginally.

B) INCORRECT:

The skin of the lateral thigh is innervated by the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. Anesthetic block of this nerve would not be helpful in performing an episiotomy.

C) INCORRECT:

The gluteus medius muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve is purely a motor nerve, so injection of local anesthetic would produce muscle paralysis without accompanying anesthesia. Other muscles innervated by the superior gluteal nerve include the gluteus minimus and tensor fascia lata.

D) CORRECT:

The external anal sphincter, along with the external urethral sphincter, levator ani, bulbospongiosus, and ischiocavernosus muscles are motor targets of the pudendal nerve. Sensory innervation is to the perineum, clitoris, labia, and anal canal. Pudendal nerve block is sometimes used to provide anesthesia during surgical procedures involving the perineum (e.g., episiotomy) or during the second stage of labor if epidural anesthesia is no longer feasible. The ischial spine is usually used as a landmark for injection to locate the pudendal nerve, which runs in close proximity to this bony prominence.

E) INCORRECT:

The skin of the mons pubis is innervated by the ilioinguinal nerve and iliohypogastric nerve, as well as by the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, but not by the pudendal nerve. The ilioinguinal nerve also innervates the skin of the labia majora and, in men, the skin of the proximal penis and scrotum. The iliohypogastric nerve also supplies sensation to the lateral gluteal region and motor signals to the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles. The genitofemoral nerve also supplies sensation to the proximal and anterior thigh.

F) INCORRECT:

The detrusor muscle of the bladder wall is innervated by the autonomic nervous system. The pudendal nerve, however, is a purely somatic nerve. Sympathetic input is received from the lower thoracic and upper lumbar spinal cord segments via the hypogastric nerve while parasympathetic tone is supplied by the sacral segments of the spinal cord via the pelvic splanchnic nerves.
questions.hint: The anesthesiologist has performed a pudendal nerve block to reduce sensation from the posterior perineum, vulva, and lower vagina.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital for active labor. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes and fetal weight is estimated to be at the 90th percentile for gestational age. During delivery, there is an arrest in the second stage of labor, and a vacuum-assisted delivery is performed. Postpartum examination shows a third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence most often results from detrusor muscle hyperactivity. This is a common concern in patients with multiple sclerosis or those with urinary catheters in place. Perineal lacerations, however, are not associated with the development of urge incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Formation of a vesicovaginal fistula most commonly occurs after pelvic operations such as hysterectomy, but is not a complication of third-degree perineal lacerations. This woman's laceration extended in the 6 o'clock direction (i.e., away from the bladder), making it less likely to cause a vesicovaginal fistula.
Image Description:

Urogenital fistulas are abnormal connections between the vagina and the urogenital system (e.g., vesicovaginal fistula). Urogenital fistulas can manifest with continuous urinary leakage from the vagina.

C) CORRECT:

Fecal incontinence is a common complication of third-degree perineal lacerations, which extend through the skin, vaginal mucosa, subcutaneous tissues, the external anal sphincter, and, in more severe cases, the internal anal sphincter. Disruption of the anal sphincter puts this patient at risk for this complication. Even with adequate repair at the time of delivery, this patient may still have persistent anorectal concerns (e.g., involuntary leakage of flatus or stool).

Operative delivery (i.e., the use of forceps or vacuum assistance) and fetal macrosomia are risk factors for third-degree perineal tears.
Image Description:

First degree: cutaneous to subcutaneous tissue tear (skin, fourchette, posterior vaginal wall) with no involvement of the perineal muscles

Second degree: first-degree lacerations plus laceration of the perineal muscles without involvement of the anal sphincter

Third degree: second-degree lacerations plus involvement of the external anal sphincter

Fourth degree: third-degree lacerations plus lacerations of the anterior wall of the anal canal or rectum

D) INCORRECT:

Small bowel obstruction is a very rare complication of pregnancy. It is more strongly associated with abdominal surgery and intraabdominal adhesion formation. This woman's perineal laceration would not cause small bowel obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence is associated with multiple childbirths and pelvic floor weakness, but it is not a complication of perineal tears. Multiple vaginal deliveries are an important risk factor for postpartum urinary incontinence due to excessive tension on the bladder from the gravid uterus, which can lead to urethral hypermobility.
questions.hint: Pregnancies featuring maternal gestational diabetes and fetal macrosomia pose an increased risk of obstetric complications. A third-degree perineal laceration involves the structures deep into the perineum and muscles.

questions.text: One day after undergoing surgery for a traumatic right pelvic fracture, a 73-year-old man has urinary incontinence and pain over his buttocks and scrotum. Physical examination shows right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absence of anal sphincter contraction when the skin around the anus is touched. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional neurological deficits?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of hip adductors is seen in damage to the obturator nerve, which could be caused by hip or pelvic trauma. However, symptoms would include a sensory deficit on the medial surface of the anterior thigh. Right-sided perineal hypesthesia, absent anal sphincter contraction, and urinary incontinence would not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the perineum, external genitalia, and external urethral and anal sphincter muscles. A reflex erection occurs on tactile stimulation of the genital area, which stimulates the afferent fibers of the pudendal nerve. This activates a reflex arc with the parasympathetic nervous system at the sacral roots originating at S2 to S4, forwarding the stimulus to the inferior hypogastric plexus. This, in turn, leads to relaxation of the cavernous smooth muscle, which causes vasodilation (mediated by nitric oxide) and erection. The pudendal nerve may be injured in pelvic fractures or pelvic surgeries.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired hip flexion would be consistent with damage to the femoral nerve (paralysis of iliopsoas, pectineus, rectus femoris, and sartorius muscles). The femoral nerve can also be damaged by pelvic trauma. However, it would manifest with further motor deficits, including impaired knee extension and a decreased patellar tendon reflex (paralysis of quadriceps femoris muscle). Additionally, sensory deficits of the anteromedial thigh (anterior cutaneous branches), medial lower leg, and medial edge of the foot (saphenous nerve lesion) would be expected instead of perineal hypesthesia, an absent sphincter reflex, and urinary incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic erection is caused by cortical stimulation with visual, aural, and sensory stimuli or fantasy, which activates the thoracolumbar erection center T11â€“L2 via fibers from the brain to the spine. These fibers can be damaged by spinal cord injury but are unlikely to be impaired by pelvic trauma or surgery. Furthermore, unilateral perineal hypesthesia, an absent sphincter reflex, and urinary incontinence would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

An absent cremasteric reflex can be seen in patients with damage to the ilioinguinal nerve (sensory innervation to the proximal medial aspect of the thigh) or the genitofemoral nerve (motor innervation to the cremaster muscle). However, damage to the ilioinguinal nerve results in sensory loss in the root of the penis and the anterior scrotum, and damage to the genitofemoral nerve results in decreased sensation to the anteromedial thigh, neither of which is seen here. In addition, right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absent anal sphincter contraction would not be expected.
questions.hint: The history of a recent pelvic trauma, symptoms of perineal hypesthesia, and pain in the pelvis and genitals, as well as an absent sphincter reflex and urinary incontinence, indicate a pudendal nerve injury.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 5, comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of occasional involuntary urine loss that is exacerbated by coughing, sneezing, and laughing. She has no urgency or dysuria. Physical examination shows normal appearing external genitalia, vagina, and cervix. There is a loss of urine with the Valsalva maneuver. The physician recommends doing Kegel exercises. Which of the following muscles is strengthened by these exercises?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The compressor urethrae is one of the three parts of the female external urethral sphincter. These voluntary muscles work in unison to inhibit the release of urine. Kegel exercises do not target the compressor urethrae.

B) INCORRECT:

The internal urethral sphincter is comprised of smooth muscles found at the junction of the urinary bladder and urethra. It is under involuntary control and is not targeted by Kegel exercises.

C) INCORRECT:

The sphincter urethrae is one of the three parts of the female external urethral sphincter. These voluntary muscles work in unison to inhibit the release of urine. Kegel exercises do not target the sphincter urethrae.

D) CORRECT:

The levator ani forms a major portion of the pelvic floor, along with smaller muscles (e.g., coccygeus muscle) and connective tissue. It is comprised of three parts: the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles, which all contract in synchrony. Contraction of the pelvic floor through Kegel exercises strengthens these muscles, along with the ischiocavernosus and bulbospongiosus muscles in men. Strengthening the pubococcygeus improves urinary retention in both sexes and is recommended as a first-line measure in the treatment of urinary incontinence. Strengthening of these muscles may also help men with premature ejaculation.
Image Description:

The pelvic floor is composed of three layers.
â€“ Innermost (deep) layer: contains the pelvic diaphragm (levator ani and coccygeus)
â€“ Middle layer: contains the urogenital diaphragm (the deep transverse perineal muscle)
â€“ Outermost (superficial) layer: contains the external anal sphincter and the superficial transverse perineal, ischiocavernosus, and bulbospongiosus muscles

The pelvic floor has two openings: the anterior urogenital hiatus (through which the urethra and vagina pass) and the posterior rectal hiatus (through which the rectum passes).

E) INCORRECT:

The deep transverse perineal muscles form part of the pelvic floor. These muscles function to stabilize the perineal body, a central tendinous structure essential for the integrity of the pelvic floor. Strengthening these muscles would aid in the expulsion of semen and the last portion of urine. The deep transverse perineal muscles are not targeted by Kegel exercises.
questions.hint: Kegel exercises consist of voluntary contractions of all the pelvic floor muscles, with the intention of strengthening the striated muscles of the region.

questions.text: A 53-year-old multiparous woman is scheduled to undergo elective sling surgery for treatment of stress incontinence. She has frequent loss of small amounts of urine when she coughs or laughs, despite attempts at conservative treatment. The physician inserts trocars in the obturator foramen bilaterally to make the incision and passes a mesh around the pubic bones and underneath the urethra to form a sling. During the procedure, the physician accidentally injures a nerve in the obturator foramen. The function of which of the following muscles is most likely to be affected following the procedure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The obturator internus muscle is supplied directly from the sacral plexus roots L5, S1, and S2. Although the muscle itself is dissected during midurethral sling surgery, the roots innervating this muscle pass through the greater sciatic foramen, not the obturator foramen, and are rarely damaged.

B) CORRECT:

The obturator nerve innervates the muscles of the medial compartment of the thigh, including the adductor longus, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, gracilis, external obturator, and, occasionally, the pectineus muscle. It is frequently damaged during midurethral sling surgeries, as well as by pelvic ring fractures and obturator hernias. Damage to this nerve can cause sensory deficits along the medial thigh and weakness of hip adduction.

C) INCORRECT:

The tensor fascia latae muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, which passes through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and lies in the superomedial gluteal region. The superior gluteal nerve does not pass through the obturator foramen and is not typically injured in midurethral sling surgery. Instead, this nerve is typically injured by gluteal intramuscular injections.
Image Description:

A neural network formed by the anterior (ventral) divisions of the last two lumbar nerves and the first four sacral nerves (L4â€“S4).

The illustration depicts the nerve roots and branches of the sacral plexus that supply motor and sensory innervation to the lower limbs and pelvis.

Note that the nerve roots of the pudendal nerve are variably described in the literature as S2-S4 or S1-S4 (as depicted here).

D) INCORRECT:

The transversus abdominis muscle is innervated by the iliohypogastric nerve, which passes over the quadratus lumborum muscle of the posterior abdominal wall and is at risk of injury during abdominal surgery. Midurethral sling surgery is performed in the pelvic region and does not typically endanger the iliohypogastric nerve.
Image Description:

A neural network formed by the anterior (ventral) divisions of the subcostal and first four lumbar nerves (T12â€“L4).

The illustration depicts the nerve roots and branches of the lumbar plexus that supply motor and sensory innervation to the lower limbs and pelvis.

E) INCORRECT:

The rectus femoris muscle, which is part of the quadriceps femoris muscle, is innervated by the femoral nerve. The femoral nerve lies within the psoas major muscle of the posterior abdominal wall and enters the thigh by passing underneath the inguinal ligament. It can be injured during femoral vascular access procedures, abdominal surgery, and pelvic surgery. The nerve that was injured during this patient's pelvic procedure lies in the obturator foramen, which does not contain the femoral nerve.
Image Description:

The femoral nerve is the main nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh. The saphenous nerve and the medial and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh originate from the femoral nerve.
The obturator nerve is the main nerve of the medial compartment of the thigh and exits the pelvis ventrally through the obturator foramen.
The iliohypogastric, ilioinguinal, genitofemoral, and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves are pure sensory nerves that arise directly from the lumbar plexus.
The common fibular nerve (a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve) branches into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves at or just below the neck of the fibula.

Cutaneous innervation of the foot is supplied by the saphenous nerve medially and the sural nerve laterally.
Cutaneous innervation of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by branches of the superficial fibular nerve, with the exception of the first interdigital space, which is supplied by a branch of the deep fibular nerve.

F) INCORRECT:

The semitendinosus muscle is innervated by the sciatic nerve, which passes through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis muscle and lies in the gluteal region. The sciatic nerve does not pass through the obturator foramen and is not typically injured during midurethral sling surgery. Instead, this nerve is typically injured during hip joint surgeries and by gluteal intramuscular injections.
Image Description:

The nerves of the lower extremity arise from the lumbar and sacral plexuses.
The sciatic nerve (L4â€“S3), inferior gluteal nerve, posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and pudendal nerve exit the pelvis dorsally through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis muscle. The superior gluteal nerve is the only nerve that exits the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle.
The sciatic nerve branches at the popliteal fossa into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

The cutaneous nerves penetrate through the deep fascia and enter the subcutaneous plane to supply their dermatomes.
The sural nerve is a cutaneous nerve formed by the union of the medial sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the tibial nerve) and the lateral sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the common peroneal nerve).
The medial and lateral plantar nerves are the cutaneous terminal branches of the tibial nerve.
questions.hint: The nerve passing through the obturator foramen is the obturator nerve, which is at risk of being injured during pelvic surgeries or as a result of pelvic trauma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a 1-year history of constipation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has bowel movements 1â€“2 times a week and sometimes has to use his fingers for stool evacuation. Defecation is painful and preceded by a sense of bowel obstruction. Flexible sigmoidoscopy two months prior showed normal results. His current medication is a laxative. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Digital examination of the rectum shows an increased resting and squeezing tone of the anal sphincter. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by dysfunction of which of the following processes?

choices.text: Involuntary relaxation of the external anal sphincter
Involuntary relaxation of the iliococcygeus muscle
Involuntary relaxation of the pubococcygeus muscle
Voluntary relaxation of the internal anal sphincter
Voluntary relaxation of the puborectalis muscle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Relaxation of the external anal sphincter allows expulsion of stool into the anal canal during the defecation process. Dysfunction in relaxation of the external anal sphincter also leads to increased tonus during digital rectal examination and can cause constipation, both of which are seen in this patient. However, the external anal sphincter is a voluntary, not an involuntary, muscle.

B) INCORRECT:

The iliococcygeus muscle is part of the levator ani, a muscle group that is important for maintaining continence and providing stability of the abdominal and pelvic organs. The iliococcygeus muscle is voluntary, not involuntary, and has no role in the defecation process, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's increased rectal tonus and constipation.

C) INCORRECT:

The pubococcygeus muscle is part of the levator ani, a muscle group that is important for maintaining continence and providing stability of the abdominal and pelvic organs. Pubococcygeus muscle dysfunction (failure to relax) can lead to increased tonus on digital rectal examination. However, the pubococcygeal muscle is not directly involved in defecation and is, therefore, unlikely to be responsible for this patient's chronic constipation. Additionally, the pubococcygeus is a voluntary, not an involuntary muscle.

D) INCORRECT:

Relaxation of the internal anal sphincter occurs once intestinal contents have reached the rectum. At this stage, a small amount of rectal content is expelled into the anal canal for anal sampling. Dysfunction in relaxation of the internal anal sphincter would also lead to increased tonus on digital rectal examination and constipation. However, the internal anal sphincter is an involuntary, not a voluntary muscle.

E) CORRECT:

The puborectalis muscle, part of the levator ani muscle group, must be voluntarily relaxed to facilitate defecation. This patient most likely has pelvic dyssynergia, which leads to increased sphincter tonus and inability to empty the anal canal. Normally, defecation is enabled by simultaneous voluntary contraction of abdominal muscles and relaxation of the external anal sphincter and puborectalis muscle.

Weakening of the puborectalis muscle is associated with fecal incontinence.
Image Description:

The pelvic floor is composed of three layers.
â€“ Innermost (deep) layer: contains the pelvic diaphragm (levator ani and coccygeus)
â€“ Middle layer: contains the urogenital diaphragm (the deep transverse perineal muscle)
â€“ Outermost (superficial) layer: contains the external anal sphincter and the superficial transverse perineal, ischiocavernosus, and bulbospongiosus muscles

The pelvic floor has two openings: the anterior urogenital hiatus (through which the urethra and vagina pass) and the posterior rectal hiatus (through which the rectum passes).
questions.hint: This patient most likely has primary constipation due to an inability to coordinate relaxation of the pelvic muscles that are involved in defecation.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman reports several weeks of pain in the right hip. She typically runs 3 to 5 miles every day but has stopped her running routine because of worsening pain during the past 3 weeks. She recalls no particular trauma. Her pain is localized mainly over the anterior groin. The pain is exacerbated by walking, and pivoting to the right produces pain and a catching sensation in the hip.
Examination of the right hip reveals mild limitation in internal rotation but an otherwise full range of motion. The patient has pain at the extreme of flexion. Simultaneous internal rotation and adduction of the flexed hip causes discomfort. Resisted hip flexion does not cause pain, and there is no tenderness over the lateral aspect of the hip girdle. Her straight-leg raise is normal. Examination of the left hip is normal.
A radiograph of the pelvis reveals mild dysplasia of the right hip but is otherwise normal.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patientâ€™s pain?

choices.text: Referred pain related to lumbar radiculopathy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is most often apparent on radiography and generally occurs in children with obesity.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis is unlikely in a young adult (even with a history of hip dysplasia), particularly when a radiograph shows no evidence of this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Iliopsoas tendinopathy is another cause of anterior hip pain in runners. Typical examination findings include pain upon resisted hip flexion. Bone radiographs are normal.

D) CORRECT:

The labrum is the fibrocartilaginous tissue attached to the rim of the acetabulum. Labrum tears, which are common in athletes, can happen after twisting or pivoting injuries â€” or insidiously without a clear history of trauma. Typical examination findings include pain upon maximum flexion and upon simultaneous internal rotation and adduction of the flexed hip.

In the majority of young adults with labrum tears, a radiograph reveals osseous abnormalities, such as acetabular dysplasia or diminished offset at the femoral head-neck junction. Those risk factors for labrum tear can provide a clue to the diagnosis. A magnetic resonance arthrogram is the preferred imaging modality for detecting labrum tears.

Key learning point: Hip pain in a young adult athlete with femoroacetabular dysplasia is most likely to be attributable to a labrum tear.

E) INCORRECT:

Referred pain related to lumbar radiculopathy is unlikely; the patient has no back pain, and she has discomfort with maneuvers involving hip range of motion.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old multiparous woman is in active labor in the Delivery Room and receives a pudendal nerve block immediately before an operative vaginal delivery. After delivery, she reports reduced pain in the perineal region but continues to experience deep pressure and discomfort in the rectum. Examination shows no lacerations beyond the perineum, and vital signs are normal. The obstetric team confirms adequate perineal anesthesia during repair.
She asks why she still feels rectal pain. Which of the following best explains her ongoing discomfort?

choices.text: Undetected extension of episiotomy into rectum
Referred pain from lumbosacral plexus injury
Unblocked visceral afferents from pelvic splanchnic nerves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An episiotomy extending into the rectum could cause pain not blocked by a pudendal nerve block. However, examination showed no lacerations beyond the perineum, and there are no signs of rectal injury, such as bleeding or infection, making this explanation unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A lumbosacral plexus injury would typically cause neurological deficits like radiating pain or motor weakness in the lower extremities, which are not present. The pudendal nerve block targets the perineum, not deeper pelvic structures, making a plexus injury an unlikely cause of rectal discomfort.

C) CORRECT:

The rectum receives visceral sensory input from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2â€“S4), which convey deep, visceral pain and pressure sensations. A pudendal nerve block primarily anesthetizes the somatic afferents of the perineum and lower external structures, sparing the autonomic, visceral fibers. This explains why the patient experiences rectal discomfort despite effective perineal anesthesia, as the visceral afferents remain unblocked.

Key learning point: The pudendal nerve block anesthetizes the perineum, but the rectum remains sensitive as it is innervated by autonomic nerves, not the pudendal nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

Inadequate infiltration near the ischial spine could result in incomplete pudendal nerve block, but the confirmation of effective perineal anesthesia indicates adequate coverage. The pudendal nerve does not innervate deeper rectal structures, so inadequate infiltration would not explain isolated deep rectal discomfort.

questions.text: You are caring for a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation who is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, and fetal weight is estimated at the 90th percentile for gestational age. During delivery, there is an arrest in the second stage of labor, and you perform a vacuum-assisted delivery. On postpartum examination, she is found to have a third-degree vaginal laceration extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position. Which one of the following complications is she most likely to experience?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small bowel obstruction is a very rare complication of pregnancy. It is more strongly associated with abdominal surgery and intraabdominal adhesion formation. This woman's perineal laceration would not cause small bowel obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence most often results from detrusor muscle hyperactivity. This is a common concern in patients with multiple sclerosis or those with urinary catheters in place. Perineal lacerations, however, are not associated with the development of urge incontinence.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence is associated with multiple childbirths and pelvic floor weakness, but it is not a complication of perineal tears. Multiple vaginal deliveries are an important risk factor for postpartum urinary incontinence due to excessive tension on the bladder from the gravid uterus, which can lead to urethral hypermobility.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of a vesicovaginal fistula most commonly occurs after pelvic operations such as hysterectomy, but is not a complication of third-degree perineal lacerations. This woman's laceration extended in the 6 o'clock direction (i.e., away from the bladder), making it less likely to cause a vesicovaginal fistula.

E) CORRECT:

Fecal incontinence is a common complication of third-degree perineal lacerations, which extend through the skin, vaginal mucosa, subcutaneous tissues, the external anal sphincter, and, in more severe cases, the internal anal sphincter. Disruption of the anal sphincter puts this patient at risk for this complication. Even with adequate repair at the time of delivery, this patient may still have persistent anorectal concerns (e.g., involuntary leakage of flatus or stool).

Operative delivery (i.e., the use of forceps or vacuum assistance) and fetal macrosomia are risk factors for third-degree perineal tears.

Key learning point: Third-degree perineal lacerations, which involve the anal sphincter, commonly lead to fecal incontinence due to disruption of sphincter function.
Image Description:

First degree: cutaneous to subcutaneous tissue tear (skin, fourchette, posterior vaginal wall) with no involvement of the perineal muscles

Second degree: first-degree lacerations plus laceration of the perineal muscles without involvement of the anal sphincter

Third degree: second-degree lacerations plus involvement of the external anal sphincter

Fourth degree: third-degree lacerations plus lacerations of the anterior wall of the anal canal or rectum
questions.hint: Pregnancies featuring maternal gestational diabetes and fetal macrosomia pose an increased risk of obstetric complications. A third-degree perineal laceration involves the structures deep into the perineum and muscles.
